designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The  Government  of  Uzbekistan  has  expressed  its  commitment  to  developing  solar 
energy and becoming the regional knowledge hub for solar technologies. The government 
requested the assistance of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) in promoting solar energy 
development in December 2010.  
 
2.  A  consultation  mission  was  fielded  in  March  2011  where  the  government  and  the 
mission  agreed,  through  the  signing  of  a  memorandum  of  understanding,  on  the  scope, 
implementation  arrangements,  cost,  financing  arrangements,  and  the  consultant’s  terms  of 
reference of the proposed policy and advisory technical assistance (TA).1 The content of the TA 
was reconfirmed during a technical assistance fact-finding mission fielded in May 2011. The 
design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Uzbekistan is endowed with rich coal, oil, and gas reserves. The country has about 1.8 
trillion cubic meters of proven natural gas reserves, 590 million barrels of proven oil reserves, 
and about 3.0 billion tons of recoverable coal reserves. However, Uzbekistan’s primary energy 
demand is projected to increase from 48.5 million tons of oil equivalent (Mtoe) in 2006 to 72.6 
Mtoe  in  2030,  an  annual  growth  rate  of  1.8%.  To  conserve  its  depleting  resources,  the 
government, in its Welfare Improvement Strategy,2 called for reduced use of natural gas through 
the introduction of energy efficiency and renewable energy technologies.3  
 
4.  The most promising source of renewable energy in Uzbekistan is solar energy. The 
country has abundant solar irradiance (annual total global horizontal irradiance) of 1,400–1,800 
kilowatt-hours per square meter, which is comparable to leading countries in solar energy such 
as Germany and Spain. In fact, Uzbekistan was selected as the optimum location in the former 
Soviet Union to establish a solar furnace to conduct material  science research in a high-
temperature environment created by concentrating solar energy. With such foundation, the 
government aims not only to develop solar energy but also to become the region’s knowledge 
hub for solar technologies. 
 
5.  Despite its solar resource potential, a pool of solar energy experts, and abundant land 
on which to develop solar energy, limited exposure to modern solar technology and applications 
have impeded Uzbekistan from effectively harnessing its solar resources. In addition, it does not 
have sufficient reliable solar irradiance data or an enabling environment for such development. 
The TA will contribute to the deployment of solar energy in Uzbekistan by removing such 
impediments and by preparing feasibility studies for both pilot and commercial solar energy 
projects.  
 
6.  The harnessing of indigenous solar energy as a result of the TA will diversify the energy 
mix and reduce greenhouse gas emissions from the thermal power plants that make up 86% of 
the country’s installed generation capacity. Environmental and health benefits are also expected

from reduced local pollutants from combustion of fossil fuels. Since the power grid in Central 
Asia connects the countries in the region, the benefit of solar energy deployment in Uzbekistan 
is expected to extend beyond its borders. 
 
7.  The policy and advisory TA is expected to complement the ongoing small-scale capacity 
development TA4 approved on 15 August 2011. Under the small-scale capacity development 
TA, a modern solar energy institute will be designed and the capacity of solar energy experts 
developed. The institute will be the knowledge hub for solar energy. It will draft laws and 
regulations  related  to  renewable  energy,  provide  assistance  to  solar  energy  project 
development, and transfer solar technology to local industries in Uzbekistan as well as in 
neighboring countries with rich solar resources. The institute is expected to be established out 
of the existing Scientific-Production Association on Solar Physics, which is the implementing 
agency for both the policy and advisory TA and the small-scale capacity development TA. The 
government will allocate the necessary budget to establish the solar energy institute.  The policy 
and advisory TA will provide capacity development opportunities. Ultimately, it is envisaged that 
the  synergy  between  the  policy  and  advisory  TA  and  the  ongoing  small-scale  capacity 
development TA will result in the creation of a solar industry in Uzbekistan, bringing vast 
economic benefits to the local economy and beyond.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  The TA will promote solar energy development in Uzbekistan through (i) creating an 
enabling environment for solar energy development, (ii) on-site solar resource assessment, and 
(iii) solar energy project preparation.  
 
9.  The TA impact will be an increase in environmentally sustainable and efficient power 
generation, with installed capacity of renewable energy increasing by 100 megawatts within 5 
years of completion of the TA. The outcome will be increased readiness for solar application in 
Uzbekistan—at least one commercial-scale solar power plant is committed for development by 
2013, and solar energy will be used for off-grid applications by 2013. The projects prepared 
through the TA will be considered by ADB for financing through both sovereign and private 
sector operations. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  The TA will have the following activities and outputs:  
 
(i)  create  an  enabling  environment  for  solar  energy  development  through 
recommendations  on  policy,  legal,  and  regulatory  reforms  conducive  to  the 
introduction and development of solar energy and to private sector participation; 
(ii)  formulate a solar energy development road map;  
(iii)  confirm solar resource availability through on-site solar irradiance measurement; 
produce  satellite-model-based  national  solar  resource  map  with  overlay  of 
geographical  information  system  data  to  screen  for  potential  solar  energy 
development sites.  For up to six sites, create satellite-model-based 11-year data 
series corrected using 12 months of on-site measurement data; 
                                                
4 ADB. 2009. Technical Assistance to the Republic of Uzbekistan for the Design and Strengthening of the Solar 
Energy Institute. Manila

3 
(iv)  prepare up to six feasibility studies for solar energy projects including at least two 
pilot-scale demonstration projects and two commercial-scale projects.  
 
11.  The  projects  are  to  include  photovoltaic  and  concentrated  solar  thermal  power 
technologies, integrated solar combined cycle technology, and other distributed uses of solar 
energy.  The feasibility studies will include project design documents for the Clean Development 
Mechanism or other required documentation for carbon financing applications. The scope of 
works of the TA is the first of its kind in Uzbekistan, and it is expected that the country’s capacity 
to develop solar energy will be strengthened through its implementation. 
 
12.  For on-site solar irradiance measurement, six complete meteorological stations with 
rotating shadowband pyranometers will be procured and installed by the consultants in up to six 
potential project sites. In one complete meteorological station an air transmissivity sensor5 and 
pyrheliometer with tracker will be procured and installed to calibrate the rotating shadowband 
pyranometers. In addition, one set of specialized computers will be procured for data collection 
and analysis. All equipment will be procured in accordance with ADB's Procurement Guidelines 
(2010, as amended from time to time). All equipment procured by the consultants under the TA 
will be handed over to the implementing agency upon delivery. All disbursements under the TA 
will be in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as 
amended from time to time). 
 
13.  It is a major assumption that the government will remain engaged in solar  energy 
development for the relatively long implementation period of the TA. A major risk is that reliable 
continuous data are not obtained through on-site measurement. To mitigate this risk, proper 
installation, maintenance, and frequent data verification will be conducted. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $1.5 million equivalent. The TA will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund ($1,000,000 from TASF-IV  and  $500,000 
from TASF-other sources). The government will provide counterpart contribution in the form of 
land  and  required  works  (e.g.,  leveling,  security  fences)  for  the  installation  of  the  on-site 
measurement stations, telecommunications cost for data logging, daily maintenance of on-site 
measurement stations, counterpart staff, counterpart staff per diems, office space and other in-
kind contributions. The government will also guarantee that all equipment purchased under the 
TA and brought into Uzbekistan will be exempted from all forms of taxes and duties. The cost 
estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  The Ministry of Finance will be the executing agency because development of solar 
energy is a national strategic priority, not only for the supply of energy but also to create a local 
industry  around  solar  energy  to  boost  economic  activity.  The  ministry  will  supervise  the 
implementation of the TA and coordinate with the activities of the separate small-scale capacity 
development TA. The Ministry of Finance will also be responsible for evaluating and assessing 
the  outputs  of  the  policy  and  advisory  TA.  The  Scientific-Production  Association  on  Solar 
Physics will be the implementing agency. The association is responsible for the operation of the 
solar furnace and supervising the various research institutions engaged in the use of solar 
                                                
5 Transmissivity is a measure of how much light passes through a substance (such as glass or air).  Air transmissivity 
sensors are used to monitor solar radiation, weather, visibility, or pollution.

4   
energy,  including  the  Physical-Technical  Institute  and  Material  Science  Institute.  The 
association will assign counterpart staff to work with the consultants on a daily basis. The 
Ministry of Finance and Scientific-Production Association on Solar Physics  will establish a 
steering committee to provide guidance and oversee implementation of the TA. 
 
16.  The TA will be implemented over 21 months from January 2012 to September 2013. It 
will require 40 person-months (12 experts) of international and 40 person-months (8 experts) of 
national consultants. Required positions include a solar development expert; solar policy, laws, 
and regulations expert; solar resource assessment expert; photovoltaic expert; concentrated 
solar thermal power expert; and integrated solar combined cycle expert. The terms of reference 
for consultants are in Appendix 3. ADB will engage a consulting firm in accordance with ADB's 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). The firm will be 
recruited through the quality- and cost-based selection method using a full technical proposal. 
The quality–cost ratio will be 90:10 as the TA requires a high level of specialized technical 
expertise.  
 
17.  The outputs of the TA will be disseminated through workshops and through the Asia 
Solar Energy Forum. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,500,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Uzbekistan for Solar Energy Development, and hereby reports this action to 
the Board.

8  Appendix 3 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The assignment is expected to be executed over 21 months requiring 40 person-months 
of international and 40 person-months of national consultants. 
 
A.  Scope of Works 
 
2.  The scope of works of the consulting service is as follows:  
 
(i)  Component  A:  Creating an enabling environment:  A recommendation on policy, 
laws, and regulations conducive to the introduction and development of solar energy, 
including an enabling environment for private sector participation and a phased plan for 
the development of solar energy. 
(ii) Component  B:  Solar  resource  assessment:  Satellite-model-based  national  solar 
resource  map  with  overlay  of  geographical  information  system  data  to  screen  for 
potential solar energy development sites, procurement and installation of appropriate on-
site measurement stations in up to six sites, and satellite-model-based 11-year data 
series corrected using 12 months of on-site measurement data. 
(iii) Component  C:  Project  preparation:  Feasibility  studies  for  up  to  six  solar  energy 
development  projects  including  two  pilot-scale  demonstration  projects  and  two 
commercial-scale projects. The projects are to include photovoltaic and concentrated 
solar thermal power technologies, integrated solar combined cycle technology, and other 
distributed uses of solar energy.  
 
B.  Terms of Reference 
 
3.  The terms of reference for the policy and advisory TA consultants are as follows. 
 
1.  International Consultants (40.0 person-months) 
 
4.  Solar  development  expert -  team leader (5.5  person-months). The  expert  should 
preferably have a degree and professional certification in solar power, renewable energy, and  
electrical or chemical or materials engineering. Full-time staff of proposing firm (including joint-
ventures and associations) is highly preferable. The expert should preferably have relevant 
professional experience of 15 years or more, and must be conversant in the various solar 
energy  technologies  including  photovoltaic,  concentrated  solar  thermal  power  (CSP),  and 
integrated solar combined cycle (ISCC). The expert should possess working knowledge about 
Clean  Development  Mechanism  (CDM)  project  development  and  other  carbon  financing 
facilities. The expert will have overall responsibility in assessing the solar energy development 
potential, selecting priority sites, supervising on-site measurement, data analysis and modeling, 
selection of appropriate technologies, feasibility studies, the solar development road map, etc. 
As the team leader, the international expert will be responsible for the progress and quality of 
the consulting service assignment as well as the performance of the team members.  
 
5.  Solar policy, laws and regulations expert (3.0 person-months). The expert should 
preferably have a degree in law, public administration, institution or similar. Full-time staff of 
proposing firm (including joint-ventures and associations) is highly preferable. The expert should 
preferably have relevant professional experience of 10 years or more, including knowledge of 
international carbon financing mechanisms such as CDM. The expert will be responsible for 
reviewing the policies, laws, regulations and standards related to solar energy development in 
Uzbekistan. Through comparison with countries leading in solar development, the expert will

Appendix 3  9 
conduct  a  strength-weakness-opportunity-threat  (SWOT)  analysis  and  recommend  changes 
and/or  introduction  of  policies,  laws,  regulations  and  standards  to  create  an  enabling 
environment for solar energy development. The expert will also prepare a solar development 
road map (phase-wise for 5-, 10-, 20-year horizon). The international expert will guide the 
national expert. 
 
6.  Solar resource assessment expert (4.0 person-months). The expert should preferably 
have a degree and professional certification in solar power, renewable energy, and electrical or 
chemical or materials engineering. Full-time staff of proposing firm (including joint-ventures and 
associations)  is  highly  preferable. The  expert should  preferably  have  relevant  professional 
experience of 10 years or more. The expert will be responsible for assessing solar potential and 
solar power development potential through solar resource maps, geographical information of 
relevant factors for consideration, data analysis and interpretation of on-site data measurement 
and hourly time-series, calculation of solar energy generation, etc. Data from the instruments 
shall be observed and recorded for one year. It will be telemetered and filtered regularly by the 
expert. The satellite model will be updated regularly to match the observed data. If any anomaly 
is detected in the measure signals, the expert will check and ensure the proper functionality of 
the instrument to prevent data loss. Once an entire year of observations is available, the 
satellite model shall be adjusted to correspond to the observed data. The Expert will be required 
to  submit  a  minimum  of  two  updates  aside  from  occasional  request(s)  from  ADB.  The 
international expert will guide the national expert. 
 
7.  On-site measurement expert (3.5 person-months). The expert should preferably have 
a degree and professional certification in meteorology, solar power, renewable energy, and 
electrical or chemical or materials engineering. Full-time staff of proposing firm (including joint-
ventures and associations) is highly preferable. The expert should preferably have relevant 
professional experience of 10 years or more. The expert will be responsible for studying and 
recommending  the  on-site  measurement  stations  and  associated  software  and  hardware, 
prepare  specifications,  procure  the  above  equipments,  supervise  installation,  monitor  the 
performance of the equipments, train personnel on daily maintenance, etc. The expert will also 
inspect the instruments at least once during the one year measurement period to control the 
functionality of the sensors and properly calibrate the equipment. The expert, together with the 
solar resource assessment expert, will also conduct analysis of the observed data. 
 
8.  Remote sensing/Geographical Information System expert (2.5 person-months). The 
expert should preferably have a degree and professional certification in information technology, 
remote  sensing,  geography,  geographical  information  system  (GIS),  solar  power,  and/or 
renewable energy. The expert should preferably have relevant professional experience of 10 
years or more. The expert will be responsible for collecting and analyzing relevant information 
on factors to be considered for the screening of solar energy development sites, including 
satellite based solar irradiance data, slope, land use, meteorological data, water body, roads, 
railroads, power stations, power transmission lines, natural gas facilities, population, national 
parks, protected area, etc. The expert will compile all information in GIS format including those 
observed solar and meteorological data from the on-site measurement stations. 
 
9.  Carbon financing expert (1.5 person-months). The expert should preferably have a 
degree in engineering or economics or environment, with total professional experience of at 
least 5 years of which a minimum of 3 years should be on project development using CDM or 
similar. The expert should be responsible for conducting technical carbon financing assessment 
to estimate greenhouse gas emission reductions and to identify baseline scenarios, relevant 
laws/regulations,  and  barriers/risks  in  support  of  additionality  proofs.  The  expert  will  also

prepare the draft project design documents based on the assessment for CDM and documents 
required for other types of carbon finance.   
 
10.  Photovoltaic expert (4.0 person-months). The expert should preferably have a degree 
and professional certification in solar power, renewable energy, and electrical or chemical or 
materials  engineering.  Full-time  staff  of  proposing  firm  (including  joint-ventures  and 
associations)  is  highly  preferable. The  expert should  preferably  have  relevant  professional 
experience of 10 years in development of solar PV projects. The expert will be responsible for 
selecting  priority  sites,  selection  of  appropriate  technologies,  and  preparation  of  feasibility 
study(ies) on the selected PV projects. 
 
11.  Concentrating solar power expert (4.0 person-months). The expert should preferably 
have a degree and professional certification in solar power, renewable energy, and electrical or 
chemical or materials engineering. Full-time staff of proposing firm (including joint-ventures and 
associations)  is  highly  preferable. The  expert should  preferably  have  relevant  professional 
experience of 10 years in development of CSP projects. The expert will be responsible for 
selecting  priority  sites,  selection  of  appropriate  technologies,  and  preparation  of  feasibility 
study(ies) on the selected CSP projects. 
 
12.   Integrated  solar  combined  cycle  expert  (3.5  person-months).  The  expert  should 
preferably have a degree and professional certification in solar power, renewable energy, and 
electrical or chemical or materials engineering. Full-time staff of proposing firm (including joint-
ventures and associations) is highly preferable. The expert should preferably have relevant 
professional  experience  of  10  years  in  development  of  ISCC  projects.  The  expert  will  be 
responsible for selecting priority sites, selection of appropriate technologies, and preparation of 
feasibility study(ies) on the selected ISCC projects. 
 
13.  Economic  and  financial  analysis  expert  (3.5  person-months).  The  expert  should 
preferably have a degree in economics, finance or similar. The expert should preferably have 
relevant  professional  experience  of  10  years  or  more.  The  expert  will  be  responsible  for 
performing economic and financial analysis of the solar development subprojects in accordance 
with ADB’s guidelines. Benefits should include potential revenues from carbon credits. The 
international expert will guide the national expert. 
 
14.  Environmental safeguard expert (2.5 person-months). The expert should preferably 
have a degree in environmental sciences or similar. The expert should preferably have relevant 
professional experience of 10 years or more. The expert will be responsible for conducting 
environmental safeguard due diligence in accordance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement 
(2009). The international expert will guide the national expert. 
 
15.  Social safeguard expert (2.5 person-months) The expert should preferably have a 
degree  in  sociology,  anthropology  or  similar.  The  expert  should  preferably  have  relevant 
professional experience of 10 years or more. The expert will be responsible for conducting 
social safeguard due diligence in accordance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009). 
The  international  expert  will  guide  the  national  experts  on  social  safeguard  and  social 
development. 
 
2.  National Consultants (40.0 person-months)

energy,  and/or  electrical/chemical/material  engineering.  The  expert  should  preferably  have 
relevant professional experience of 10 years or more. The expert, as the deputy team leader,

17.  Solar policy, laws and regulations expert (4.0 person-months). The expert should 
preferably have a degree in law, public administration, institution or similar. The expert should 
preferably have relevant professional experience of 5 years or more. The expert will assist the 
international solar policy, laws and  regulations expert. 
 
18.  Solar resource measurement/assessment expert (8.0 person-months). The expert 
should  preferably  have  a  degree  and  professional  certification  in  solar  power,  renewable 
energy,  and/or  electrical/chemical/material  engineering.  The  expert  should  preferably  have 
relevant professional experience of 5 years or more. The expert will assist the international solar 
resource assessment expert and on-site measurement expert. 
 
19.  Electrical engineer (6.0 person-months). The expert should preferably have a degree 
and professional certification in solar electrical engineering. The expert should preferably have 
relevant professional experience in designing power plants of 5 years or more. The expert will 
assist the international solar development expert, photovoltaic expert, CSP expert and ISCC 
expert. 
 
20.  Economic  and  financial  analysis  expert  (4.0  person-months).  The  expert  should 
preferably have a degree in economics, finance or similar. The expert should preferably have 
relevant professional experience of 5 years or more. The expert will assist the international 
economic and financial analysis expert. 
 
21.  Environmental safeguard expert (4.0 person-months). The expert should preferably 
have a degree in environmental sciences or similar. The expert should preferably have relevant 
professional  experience  of  5  years  or  more.  The  expert  will  assist  the  international 
environmental safeguard expert. 
 
22.  Social safeguard expert (3.0 person-months). The expert should preferably have a 
degree  in  sociology,  anthropology  or  similar.  The  expert  should  preferably  have  relevant 
professional experience of 5 years or more. The expert will  assist the international  social 
safeguard expert with particular focus on social safeguards. 
 
23.  Social development expert (1.0 person-months). The expert should preferably have a 
degree  in  sociology,  anthropology  or  similar.  The  expert  should  preferably  have  relevant 
professional experience of 5 years or more. The expert will  assist the international  social 
safeguard expert with particular focus on conducting social analysis of the project sites.
